entry.title: New study showing the effects of fluid viscosity on cell migration now published in Nature!

link.title: New study showing the effects of fluid viscosity on cell migration now published in Nature!

entry.content:
We are delighted to share our new collaborative work led by the Konstantopoulos Lab at Johns Hopkins University, now published in Nature, showing that elevated viscosity counterintuitively increases cell motility and imprints mechanical memory in tumor cells enabling them to disseminate more efficiently in vivo. Find the publication here.

Gallery
entry.summary: We are delighted to share our new collaborative work led by the Konstantopoulos Lab at Johns Hopkins University, now published in Nature, showing that elevated viscosity counterintuitively increases cell motility and imprints mechanical memory in tumor cells enabling them to disseminate more efficiently in vivo. Find the publication here.

entry.title: Graduate student Farnaz Hemmati wins 3rd place in the 2022 Graduate Engineering Research Showcase

link.title: Graduate student Farnaz Hemmati wins 3rd place in the 2022 Graduate Engineering Research Showcase

entry.content:
We are delighted to announce that Farnaz Hemmati, a graduate student at the Mistriotis Lab, received the 3rd place award in the 2022 Graduate Engineering Research Showcase. The overall event was centered on a poster presentation for graduate students from all engineering departments to present their research. The research presentation was three hours long followed by an awards banquet. Congratulations Farnaz! üéâ

Gallery

The research presentation was three hours long followed by an awards banquet. Congratulations Farnaz! üéâ

entry.title: Mistriotis lab @ BMES 2022
entry.content:
The Mistriotis lab is excited to attend the BMES 2022 Conference in San Antonio, Texas! On October 13th, our graduate student Farnaz Hemmati presented her exciting work and gave an oral presentation with the title: ‚ÄòP53 activity governs cell life and death in confinement‚Äô. Congratulations Farnaz!üéâ

entry.title: Breast Cancer Awareness Month
entry.content: This Breast Cancer Awareness Month we would like to express our immense gratitude to Breast Cancer Research Foundation of Alabama‚Äôs support to Mistriotis Lab which will allow us to better understand how breast cancer cells invade other organs for the development of new therapeutic strategies.
entry.summary: This Breast Cancer Awareness Month we would like to express our immense gratitude to Breast Cancer Research Foundation of Alabama‚Äôs support to Mistriotis Lab which will allow us to better understand how breast cancer cells invade other organs for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

entry.title: Dr. Mistriotis named Ginn Faculty Achievement Fellow

link.title: Dr. Mistriotis named Ginn Faculty Achievement Fellow

entry.content:
We are pleased to announce that Dr. Mistriotis has been awarded the Ginn Faculty Achievement Fellowship. The Samuel Ginn College of Engineering recognized Dr. Mistriotis for his outstanding and ongoing contributions to the college.

Tweet

entry.title: Graduate student Ayuba Akinpelu on the GINNing Podcast!

link.title: Graduate student Ayuba Akinpelu on the GINNing Podcast!

entry.content:
On the latest episode of the award-winning GINNing Podcast, Ayuba Akinpelu, Ph.D. student in the Mistriotis Lab discussed his research on cancer cell microenvironments. Find the recording here!

entry.title: Mistriotis Lab receives National Institute of Health (NIH) NIGMS MIRA grant!

link.title: Mistriotis Lab receives National Institute of Health (NIH) NIGMS MIRA grant!

entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce that the Mistriotis Lab has received the National Institutes of Health Maximizing Investigator‚Äôs Research Award (MIRA) from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS). Congrats to all members of the Mistriotis Lab whose hard work made this achievement possible! üéâ

entry.title: Mistriotis lab receives Career Development Award from the American Heart Association

link.title: Mistriotis lab receives Career Development Award from the American Heart Association

entry.content:
We are excited to announce that our lab has been awarded a Career Development Award from the American Heart Association. The grant is entitled ‚ÄúThe contributions of cytokinesis proteins to smooth muscle cell function in health and disease‚Äù and will support us until 03/31/2025.

Find more information about the American Heart Association here.
entry.summary: We are excited to announce that our lab has been awarded a Career Development Award from the American Heart Association. The grant is entitled ‚ÄúThe contributions of cytokinesis proteins to smooth muscle cell function in health and disease‚Äù and will support us until 03/31/2025.
